title: Indian River County Primary Election 2024 : Candidates reply to questionnaires
body_text:
Indian River County Primary Election 2024: Candidates reply to questionnaires
In June, we began to ask candidates to fill out questionnaires to help you understand your choices on the ballot.
The following candidate responses were not edited.
Our editorial board planned to interview candidates in July participating in the Aug. 20 primary. Our main focus was on those races that could lead to a presumptive officeholder. The editorial board planned to consider making recommendations in those races.

Why are you running for office?
I was raised with the motto, "If you are going to be part of your community, you must take part in your community". This is something I take to heart. Taking part in making Indian River County a better place is what motivates me. We are facing many challenges due to growth, including needed infrastructure expansion, protection of our environmental resources, lagoon health, affordable housing, expanded job opportunities and the restructuring of our county service delivery.
Smart growth, fiscal responsibility, and community involvement is the key for the future of Indian River County. We have made great strides in planning for our future by utilizing community visioning and outreach, but our work is not done and we must start implementing plans and projects in order to attain the community our residents envision for Indian River County. As we work to implement these community wide strategies, experienced leadership is more important than ever. I am committed to creating a community where we can all thrive, where our children, my son included, can buy a home, find a job and enjoy the quality of life that we all enjoy in Indian River County.
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain:
Implementation would be my top priority. We have spent the last several years planning for our future including creating the following: Indian River County Strategic Plan, Community Visioning, Urban Service Boundary Study, Utilities Master Plan, Economic Development Plan, Manatee Protection Plan, Indian River Lagoon Plan and Parks Master Plan. It is now time to take these plans and move forward with implementation. I would work to ensure these plans are used as a roadmap to drive service delivery, road expansion, water and sewer delivery, affordable housing creation, job expansion, new park locations and expansion of conservation lands to protect our water and environmental resources.
We have also worked to re-organize our county structure to be more responsive to our residents. Creating a Natural Resource Department to focus on our environment and lagoon, hiring a Planning and Development Ombudsman to manage and address customer service and the revamping of our permitting and review process to remove unnecessary red tape. I would continue to work on streamlining our processes to create a more efficient and responsive county. In doing so we will be able to create opportunities for affordable housing and job growth. We are here to serve our residents and we must do so in a way that is transparent, easy to navigate and responsive.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
Leadership, experience and community involvement.
Have you ever filed for bankruptcy? If yes, please explain: No

Why are you running for office?
I am running for a second term to continue all the great accomplishments we have made since my 2020 election. Indian River County has moved leaps and bounds over what was happening when I took office. With my fellow Commissioners and basically a new staff we have instilled a sense of teamwork, increased morale and made customer service Priority #1. All the while, handling it pretty well with the new growth we experienced during and after COVID. We still have more to do. More to save or environment and work harder on the IRL recovery. Come up with more incentives and ideas for affordable housing and improve our recreational venues and programs.
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain:
My top priority heading into my second term would be to continue the path we set while I was newly elected Commissioner, then elected Chairman in 2022-2023 to bring Indian River County into the future.
Number one of my goals in the 2020 election wand will always be is to provide strong leadership, teamwork and make customer service top priority. We are doing that by using a different playbook than what was used in the past. We have upgraded County services, put key people in vital roles to make a difference while being held accountable yet giving them the freedom to do their jobs using new ideas and innovation.
We must and are properly managing our growth. We are taking a strong look at all our comp plans and LDR's and making sure proper zoning is in place. We must also make sure we continue to keep of infrastructure needs ahead of any new or planned growth to meet our needs.
I am also continuing my commitment to our environment and natural resources. We still have more to do in regards to the lagoon. I have been a big proponent of offering a way for the county to store storm water from the IRF canals in the western part of the county to reduce that influx into our lagoon. I currently serve as Vice-Chairman of the IRLNEP and slated to be Chairman next year.
Public Safety is always on my list of top things. We must continue to have the best public safety and health programs possible but yet keeping in mind to be fiscally responsible. We are doing that and must continue on positive forward motion to keep good employees and attract new ones and provide the tools they need to get the job done.
These are what i campaigned on in 2020 and I have kept those promises and will do this and more in 2024.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
What distinguishes me from my opponents is my ability to understand how county and state government operate, to bring people together to solve issues. Next my age, as I have already been called out for that by my one of my opponents, but the fact is that I am a third generation Indian River County resident and fifth generation Floridian. I know where we have been and where we need to go. My life experiences, my previous career as a firefighter and the fact I have a proven track record of leadership and able to instill a sense of teamwork throughout my life. As a Commissioner and Chairman in 2023, I was the lead when we had to hire a new County Administrator and County Attorney along with basically a complete County re-organization. Also while Chairman I initiated joint meeting between the BOCC and City Councils to talk about our respective issue and open a positive line of communication. These are what sets me apart by providing leadership and being part of a team to make our County better.
Have you ever filed for bankruptcy? If yes, please explain:
I was a guarantor for a local business that had to file for protection under Chapter 13.

David Shaw, Vero Beach
Age: 29
Educational background:
Bachelors degree from the University of Montana
Current occupation and work history:
I am currently the regional manager of the southern division of a large agricultural family business. As well as an entrepreneur and the real estate market.
Volunteer and civic engagement: N/A
Why are you running for office?
I want to serve and protect Indian River County. We have a very unique environment that I intend to keep. We are not like our neighbors and I don’t want to see it slip away. The recent building of the Aspire and Griffon complexes off of route 60 and the only newly added job opportunities being gas stations, car washes, and storage units raised concerns. The influx of population without the proper infrastructure poses a real threat to the way of life here. Especially with the glaring issue of our (agricultural land) orange grove’s demise. We will have serious issues if the zoning changes from agriculture to high density commercial. Zoning is a crucial cornerstone, for any city. There is a lot of room for potential abuse of authority for monetary gain. With 24 nieces and nephews, I feel I have an innate obligation to them and to my fellow citizens. An obligation to make sure there’s a future that is worth looking forward to. A future that provides prosperity through well paying jobs, an infrastructure that is up to the task and suitable living arrangements. Not high density housing or careers that consist of gas stations and car washes.
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain:
There are many things that are at the top of my list. However, this particular one has my attention.
I would investigate the allocation of government funds.
The reason that this is a top priority for me is because last year our existing commissioner council gave 425 thousand dollars to The Learning Alliance, an NGO. Just prior to doing so, The Learning Alliance reported a profit of 19+ million dollars that fiscal year. For 2023-2024 this same NGO has requested another 630 thousand dollars of our tax dollars. These funds should have been reinvested locally to support our county and citizens. As a commissioner, I would always be taking into account the best interest of my citizens. It would be paramount to make sure our citizens tax dollars are being allocated properly and precisely rather than lining others pockets. I vow to work for our people; not the other way around.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
I’m young and full of drive. When I think about the future of our home I am thinking decades into the future. I do not want to watch our county turn into another tourist town with high rise buildings and too much traffic. I see a future where our county is as beautiful as it is now, but it will take grit to refute the incoming pressures to monopolize IRC. With my experience working as a manager, being an entrepreneur, and competing as an athlete I have overcome many challenges throughout the years. My perseverance and dedication to success has given me a strong foundation and I want to use this foundation to serve and protect for the betterment of our county. I do not view this election as a career path, but rather an opportunity and an obligation to secure a bright future for the next generation. Indian River County is worth fighting for and we have the ability to protect our home, but we need leaders that are willing to make the tough choices. Not those who will give in to appease others or reduce potential conflict. I know that if given the opportunity I will be that leader.
I have a strong moral compass combined with the will and determination to fight for our citizens and this county.
Have you ever filed for bankruptcy? If yes, please explain: N/A

Why are you running for office?
Nothing tops truly representing the will of the people and protecting their best interests. Being Mayor, now County Commissioner and holding elected office is the best job of my life. Coming in first in the 2016 and 2018 general elections for Vero Beach City Council then first again in the 2020 election for County Commissioner, District 5 is a great honor. I thank each and every individual who took the time to make his/her will known. You gave me a mandate for change and the confidence that comes with it. I never forget that all power comes from you.
Since 2016, when I became the first woman ever to start her City Council term as Mayor in the 100+-year history of Vero Beach, and continuing to today as County Commissioner, I proudly have worn my official name badge everyday everywhere I go. This simple act has served to encourage people to speak with me anytime anywhere about anything on their minds. It keeps me in-touch with their hopes and dreams, as well as their fears and concerns, for our community.
People can come away from me with the knowledge that they have direct access to local government. That their thoughts and feelings are important and will be considered in the decision-making process. It is not a one-time event; it is the start of a relationship. I invite them to contact me at any time. I view local government and my role in it as a partnership with the People. A sacred trust. A grassroots leader in touch with the People is more important than ever today. I delight in people. I relish problem-solving.
As a county, we are at a critical juncture. With the need to protect our water supply, lagoon, green spaces, and very sense of community in the face of what can become a relentless push for development. I remain committed to protecting this special place we call home and the strong sense of community that we enjoy. And I am optimistic that we can do so. With the help of our new County Administrator, initiatives to improve existing services and to plan carefully for our future have begun. I enjoy being part of that process. Envisioning and suggesting improvements. And I look forward to continuing to contribute to the process and its implementation in my second term.
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain:
Re-evaluating growth and the price we pay for it. Working with our municipalities to do so.
In simple terms, land use within our county and the quality and quantity of our water. For example, a review of the Urban Service Area currently is underway with public outreach workshops having been conducted. Related studies or plans underway include a first-time Parks & Recreation Master Plan, a Stormwater Master Plan, and a Beach Preservation Plan. All of which will become valuable tools in planning the best future for our county.
With regard to actions I’ve already taken, my initiative to create an educational native plant garden at the County Complex was completed within a year of my start on County Commission with the help of Pelican Island Audubon Society. The funding for this award-winning demonstration project largely was raised through private sources.
I’ve promoted the updating of our 1988 Geohydrology Report prepared by the US Geological Survey (federal agency) since the Soil & Water Conservation District advised us of this need in 2021. This report is the most comprehensive and specific guide to the water in our County. I voted against the creation of Community Development Districts (500+ acres at a time with financial incentives for developers) in our county in 2022, and I voted against filling in wetlands for purposes of development in 2023.
Additionally, I’ve requested that the traffic studies for proposed developments be readily available to County Commission and the Planning & Zoning Commission and that a cumulative count be kept of the amount of traffic added any given year. From my perspective, adding a subdivision should be considered within a larger context than several hundred feet from its doors. It takes years for roads and bridges to be added or even expanded. Most of us already have felt that our roadways are unable to keep up with the current increase in traffic. A large project such as the I-95 Oslo Road Exit is intended to make travel easier but the area effected will need to be planned carefully.
Other important issues currently facing us include our aging infrastructure, our economic growth, our continuing viability as an affordable home to our hardworking middle-class, and how best to address our homeless. Keeping our taxes low always is a concern.
I’ll close with the newly-minted mission statement derived from the results of Strategic Planning sessions held with Staff and County Commission: “Dedicated to Indian River County through service excellence.” Making customer service a top priority for all bodes well for our future.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
Moss = Leadership
Being Mayor. I am honored to be the only woman to start City Council as Mayor in the 100+-year history of Vero Beach.
Zudans = Lack of Leadership
My opponent, Mrs. Zudans, nominated herself for Mayor at the reorganization meeting of Vero Beach City Council last November. Her motion died for lack of a second.
Moss = Experience/Commitment to the Community
Having served two terms on Vero Beach City Council and completing my first term on County Commission, my commitment to our community is clear.
Zudans = Lack of Experience/Commitment to the Community
My opponent, Mrs. Zudans, filed to run for County Commission less than halfway through her first two-year term on Vero Beach City Council.
Moss = Accomplishments
With a mandate from the voters, I started as Mayor on 11/21/2016, and I signed the contract for the electric sale on 10/24/2017.
For details, see “How FPL-Vero Deal went from “War” to “Godsend”, reprinted with permission of Standard + Poor’s Global Market Intelligence at votelauramoss.com.
Zudans = Lack of Accomplishments
To date, with regard to the City’s single largest project, Three Corners, to say that Mrs. Zudans has been unsuccessful in bringing it to fruition is an understatement. It recently has regressed and devolved all the way back to the Request For Proposal (RFP) stage - a huge waste of time and taxpayers’ dollars. And the downward spiral includes Mrs. Zudans recusing herself from an important vote in this matter against the advice of the City Attorney. She was advised that Florida Statute required it and still refused to comply. Elected officials have an obligation to follow the law whatever their personal opinions might be.
For details, see “Three jeers for clown show on Three Corners”, Vero News, 06/13/2024

Why are you running for office?
I believe less is more. Government should focus on a limited number of things like police, fire, courts of law, and public infrastructure. For those limited rolls leaders should use restraint and common sense without picking winners and losers. Everything that the private sector and our citizens can do better than government should be left in the private sector with minimal taxes and regulation. This ultimately supports local businesses, residents and families.
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain
My top priority would be to develop the agenda for graceful growth by anticipating the needs of our infrastructure, public safety, density, and urban service boundaries while completely overhauling the building department.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
I believe that most people are capable of common sense and desire to be free of excessive government intervention in their lives and businesses. That is the attitude that I could bring to the position.

Committees: Executive Roundtable, Economic Development Council, Dasie Hope Board, Tutor, Big Brother Big Sister, Value Adjustment Board, Bill and Billy Wilson Scholarship Committee, Fellsmere Planning and Zoning.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for office because I believe in this community and school district. We raised our three children here and they graduated from our public high schools. They are all doing well and each one has completed his/ her Master's Degree.
When it states in policy that the responsibility of the education for our public school students lies with the School Board, I take that very seriously. My question each day is --- how can we continue to do better? And, are we supporting the people in our schools who need the help? This is a team effort with our parents and community members. Our public schools have a wonderful diversity and I want all children to be successful. I believe my success in all the positions I have held is an asset to me as a School Board Member. I have walked the walk.
We are on a good path with Dr. Moore and all of our district and school staffs, and I want to make sure that continues. We are an A rated school district and I am proud of that , but we must never become complacent. We can always continue to
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain:
I have three platforms, but my top priority will be recruiting and retaining teachers. In 1970, 33% of all graduates in America were in Education, now it is 9 percent. People are not going into education for several reasons, but the issue is, we still need teachers. What can we do as a community with work force housing and creating our own teachers who come back to teach with us? IRSC would be a good partner with that effort. Maybe a private-public partnership with paying for tuition the last two years at IRSC as an incentive, since the first two years are paid with the Promise Program.
In order for our students to learn, they must have great teachers. And please know, I believe we have very strong teachers and I am so glad they chose IRCSD to teach.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
I don't think there are too many people who have given as much time that I have to this school district. I started teaching here in 1980 and left in 2009 when I was Principal of SRHS. I then came back as a Principal Consultant and an Executive Director for Secondary. I am now in my 4th year in my first term as a School Board Member. What distinguishes me? I have a great work ethic and I am not afraid to roll up my sleeves to get the job done. I believe Public Education is one of the main foundations in this country and I believe we must work even harder to make sure we protect this institution. I am out in our schools and community on a regular basis --- not because I am running again, but because I love it. Knowing our community and what is going on with families is important on many levels. We are all in this together to make sure our next generation is successful in their pursuits.

Why are you running for office?
Being the biggest business in our county we need strong leaders that know how to handle business decisions. Not just on a bottom line dollar level but also on a personnel and future vision level. My son Liam will be in first grade and my daughter Fiona will be in kindergarten so I have vested interest in the success of our public schools. When I look at our 60% literacy rate and similar math scores but 95% graduation rate that does not paint a great picture of how I would expect our system to run. What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain:
As we embark on a new journey to set a fresh course for the Indian River County Sheriff's Office, it is imperative that we lay down a solid strategic plan that will guide our actions and decisions moving forward.
A strategic plan serves as our roadmap, outlining our goals, priorities, and the steps we need to take to achieve success. It will be the foundation upon which we build a more efficient, effective, and community-focused sheriff's office.
In developing our budget, my administration will take a comprehensive approach, balancing the current needs of our community with a forward-thinking perspective. We will consider factors such as the growth rate, inflation, and unfunded mandates that impact our budget, recognizing that every dollar spent ultimately comes from the hardworking taxpayers of Indian River County.
With the sheriff's office accounting for a significant portion of the county's general fund, at 54.4%, it is crucial that we find ways to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of our operations without unduly burdening our taxpayers. My team and I will be committed to exploring innovative solutions and cost-saving measures to optimize our resources and deliver top-notch services to the community.
Under my leadership, we will adopt a prudent approach to financial management. We will not allocate funds without a well-thought-out plan in place, ensuring that every dollar is spent wisely and in alignment with our strategic goals. Additionally, we will actively seek out grant opportunities to alleviate the financial strain on our taxpayers and support our initiatives for improvement and innovation.
By adhering to a strategic plan that prioritizes fiscal responsibility, transparency, and community engagement, we will pave the way for a brighter future for the Indian River County Sheriff's Office and the residents we serve.
Secondly, as we strive to be responsible stewards of the trust and resources entrusted to us by the taxpayers of Indian River County, it is essential that we conduct a thorough evaluation of every division and section within the Sheriff's Office. This evaluation will enable us to ensure that our resources and personnel are deployed in the most effective and efficient manner possible, maximizing the return on investment for our community's safety and security.
By rigorously assessing each section of the Sheriff's Office, we can identify areas of strength, areas needing improvement, and opportunities for optimization. This process will allow us to reallocate resources where needed, streamline operations, and enhance overall effectiveness in fulfilling our mission to protect and serve the residents of Indian River County.
My commitment to conducting regular evaluations underscores our dedication to transparency, accountability, and continuous improvement. By striving for excellence in the deployment of our resources and personnel, we are not only honoring the taxpayers' investment in us but also demonstrating our unwavering commitment to safeguarding the well-being and interests of our community. Through strategic evaluation and thoughtful action, we will ensure that every dollar invested in the Indian River County Sheriff's Office yields a tangible and meaningful return in the form of enhanced public safety and security for all.

Why are you running for office?
To restore Ethics, Transparency, and Accountability to the Tax Collector's office by removing the cronyism, nepotism promotions & six-figure salaries for loyalty.
Stop the revolving door of employee turnover. In the 15 years the incumbent has been in office, over 170+ employees have left. She was appointed to office in 2009 with 46 employees; I was the 61st employee to go in 2016. The office is currently budgeted for 73. That is nearing a triple turnover!
Stop excessive, wasteful spending on advertising, car allowance, Queueing System, Deputy for Hire, Beach Office, and Salaries that are not in line with experience.
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain *
Hire an HR Professional immediately. In the 15 years the incumbent has been in office, she has never had one on staff.
OPEN THE OFFICES—no more appointments are required! There will be appointment options, but I have a more efficient way to compromise with all.
Offices will open during your lunch hour and will explore Saturday hours, alternating offices.
I will meet with each employee to hear their expectations of me and share what I expect of them. I will also learn from them what their goals are to ensure they have the right tools to succeed and whether they are in the proper position for their skills/experience.
I will reassess the salaries of frontline clerks to bring them up to a competitive rate. I do not need to hire an expensive company for a salary study! The minimum wage will soon be $13 hourly, and the starting rate for a frontline clerk is only $15 hourly. Then you have the executive assistant (secretary) making $112,500 annually, even more than the finance or IT directors. Something is really wrong with that. The frontline staff are the face of your office!
Eliminate Self-Political-Branding: All signage returns to the name of the Indian River County Tax Collector, and your checks will be made payable to the same.
Eliminate unnecessary travel expenses to promote a self-serving agenda.
Re-assess the Beach office for more efficient usage or even closure.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
Having worked there, I know the position of Tax Collector is that of an Administrator, not a Legislator or a career politician.
My focus is and has always been on serving our community, not Tallahassee, and my presence in Tallahassee will be minimal.
I see ALL people equally.
I believe in self-imposed Term Limits.
My professional experience.
I would never tout or misguide taxpayers with misleading information. The incumbent touts that she is proud to have returned $40m locally. That is the job! She is required to return all excess fees; it is a fee-based office!
Have you ever filed for bankruptcy? If yes, please explain: NO

Why are you running for office?
I am proud to run for re-election as the Tax Collector of Indian River County so I can continue our legacy of sterling customer service and fiscally conservative governing. Our office has saved more than $40 million in taxpayer money that gets sent back to the county to fund critical programs that affect seniors, families and children in our community.
We will continue saving taxpayer money, while providing the best customer service possible to everyone who visits our office. I am proud of our work, and proud to serve this community I hold so dear.
What would be your top priority during your first year in office? Explain:
In my new term, we look forward to opening a new Tax Collector's Office in Fellsmere. I believe that government should be accessible for people. That's why we're making it even easier for residents in Fellsmere to obtain driver license, title and registration services, property tax services, hunting and fishing license, local business tax and many, many other services we provide.
As always, fiscal responsibility, taxpayer money savings, and sterling customer care will be guiding principles for leadership in the Tax Collector's Office of Indian River County.
What distinguishes you from your opponents in this race?
I am proud of my proven, successful record running the Tax Collector's Office of Indian River County. Before running for Tax Collector, my husband and I built a business right here in Vero Beach. When I was elected I promised to bring my unique business acumen to the Tax Collector's Office. That's how we've been able to save and return more than $40 million taxpayer dollars back to the county. That's why we have low wait times, convenient appointments, friendly and helpful staff, and rave reviews from Indian River County residents.
Have you ever filed for bankruptcy? If yes, please explain: No
